Award.AwardTitle: Structures and growth mechanisms of patterned polycrystals by polarimetric imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Bart Kahr at New York University, who will provide an understanding of the structures of polycrystalline formations, which have characteristic lenghtscales of 10 micrometers. The investigator addresses the mechanisms leading to such patterning, the optical properties of the meso-structures, and potential applications in technology and in other scientific fields. Professor Kahr proposes to attack a very complex subject, namely, to use to Mueller matrix imaging polarimetry (and related techniques) to determine the structures and growth mechanisms of banded spherulites of small organic compounds. These polycrystalline systems have been the subject of earlier studies by researchers who proposed a simple, single, growth mechanism that involved the twisting of radii. This proposal attempts to understand growth mechanisms in these self-assembling systems and in some cases reveal new phenomena. Preliminary results suggest that the twisting mechanism is not in fact the universal explanation of optical banding. Future work should lead to a much deeper understanding of the origins of the nonequilibrium pattern formation in these systems. Understanding and controlling the spontaneous formation of chiral mesoscale structures transcend fundamental questions of crystal growth, and may lead to applications from mirrors to waveguides, and in producing chiral thin films.

The broader impact of the proposed investigations will be significant. The investigator is dedicated to chemical education starting at the kindergarten level. He has found intriguing evidence that crystallography was one of the topics covered in the curriculum of the first children?s day care facilities in Germany in the 19th century. Professor Kahr has written and translated books and articles on the history of chemistry and crystallography. He is in contact with the authors of major chemistry books to insure that his findings reach undergraduate chemistry students in a timely manner. Courses for teachers are planned and these are major components of the broader outreach plan. The investigator has a track record of working with underrepresented groups of students. Professor Kahr is planning on working with local schools to bring students to his lab to participate in research projects with the hope of developing college-bound scientists who would otherwise never enter the pipeline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The year 2014 will be celebrated as the International Year of Crystallography -- largely an acknowledgement of 100 years of X-ray crystallography, the determination of the positions of atoms in single crystals. X-ray analysis has led to the vast majority of what we know about molecular structure from common table salt, to penicillin, to the enzymes that build the HIV virus. However, crystals frequently grow as ensembles of innumerable microscopic crystals. Polycrystalline ensembles have been eschewed by the chemistry community. However, as self-assembling patterns they command the attention of scientists. Their structures must be described and their mechanisms of formation articulated. This is a part of the general science of pattern formation that addresses the stripes on the zebra or the shapes of bacterial colonies. It turns out that visible light, with a wavelength 10,000 times larger than X-rays, is extraordinarily well adapted to analyzing polycrystalline structure. We have employed the latest advances in polarized light imaging to elucidate the structures and growth mechanisms of polycrystalline patterns. In essence, our project is an investigation of the complex interactions of crystals with structured light. This work has highlighted the extraordinarily common phenomenon of growth actuated twisting of crystals. Crystals are typically characterized by their straight edges and flat faces, but helical morphologies abound, especially when microcrystalline fibrils grow in aggregates. This fact has changed the way that we think about crystals and crystallography in our laboratories. Morphology under simple conditions is far more plastic than we might otherwise realize.

 

Crystalline polyhedra are prototypical material objects; light is ethereal. Yet, there has been a surprising reciprocity between crystals and light. We have learned about light and matter by their mutual interaction. Polarization and photon entanglement are crystal-optical discoveries while light scattering, as discussed above, has been unsurpassed in the characterization of crystals. We engage this dialogue through investigations of unusual crystalline materials that have informed crystal growth mechanisms and led to the design of new optical materials. This work is of great appeal to kids, because, after all, who cannot rejoice in crystals or light, two of Nature's delights. For this reason we believe we have been successful at providing research positions to high school students from an under-resourced public high school in the Bronx who might not otherwise have had the opportunity. Our partner school has a Living Environment class, but no high school chemistry or physics have ever been offered, a scandal in our view. The New York Times (27 May 2012) lamented that, "Poor school districts [across NY State] are being forced to cut electives, remedial tutoring, foreign languages...[and] face what the state commissioner of education calls educational insolvency." We have always taken on any motivated individual in our lab regardless of experience; research is learned on the job. And, while teenage students can grow, cut, and polish crystals, it is hard to go further with kids from a school that does not offer any physical science. Thus, we recognized that the our entire research group of NYU undergraduates, graduate students and postdoc had to get involved in providing the foundational instruction that would enable high school students with limited exposure the tools to succeed. More importantly, we had to impart scientific identities early on as research has shown that we will struggle to preserve those things with which we identify ourselves, even when the going gets tough. During the project period we hosted six students, several of whom will earn co-authorship of publications and several of whom have gone on to as STEM majors in the CUNY and SUNY systems. ...
